div1.p: Your letter of June 9 has been forwarded to me here in London, where I am engaged in some studies in the libraries in the British Museum, and Lucile has come with me. I am sorry that it has taken so long to reach me--by slow boat, evidently--and I am truly sorry that you are distressed, even though I can understand why you would be.

John, you must be patient with Lucile and the job she has to do. For my part, I agree with the publisher's forthright staementstatement that her manuscript is magnificent, and I am not happy that she must condense the story of Neihardt by a third or a half, even though this may make the book publishable at a price that will bring in more purchasers, more readers. But since she has had to condense the book, I applaud her sterling integrity in the way that she has done it: not content to take the easy way that she has done it: not content to take the easy way of cutting out sections or chapters entire: rather she has undertaken the task of reqwriting the enrtire book, finding a way to say what needs to be said in more economical yet felicitous terms. As you know, perhaps better than I, her task has not been spimple: it is a little like cojndensing'The Song the Indian Wars' by a third.
I think we will have good news for you soon, and I think you will like the new book.

I know what you mean about the Cavett show. I spent a bit of time, I can tell you in alerting your former students--and mine--not only to see it but also to write in to Cavett afterwards. You would be amazed and pleased to know how whole-hearted was the response. I had a letter just the other day from my friend, Dr. Hugh Seabury, at the University of Iowa, lamenting that he had got only part of the program on tape, and I was happy to be able to refer him to a place where he could get the part of the program that he had not got.

We expect to be back in Oregon in September, in time for the opening of classes. Meanwhile we will pay a visit to Young Stewart (remember him?) in Boston. He has a son now, who will be a year old in November. Stewart is doing his tour of duty in the U.S. Air Force stationed at Pease AFB, Portsmouth, New Hampshire.
We will keep in touch with you and write again soon. Meanwhile, let us hear from you again, at the address above.
